title: 109_s3455
content: The Act may be cited as the "Profiting from Access to Computer Technology (PACT) Act" or the "Child PACT Act". Definitions are provided in the Act. The Act, also known as the "Profiting from Access to Computer Technology (PACT) Act" or the "Child PACT Act", defines terms related to education and nonprofit organizations. It includes definitions for "classroom-usable" equipment and "community-based educational organization". The curr_chunk defines terms related to education and nonprofit organizations, including "educational recipient", "Federal agency", "military family recipient", and "nonprofit refurbisher". The curr_chunk defines potential educationally useful Federal equipment, including computers, peripherals, software, and telecommunications equipment, that can be upgraded at no or low cost for educational or military family recipients. The curr_chunk defines various educational institutions and entities, such as kindergarten programs, elementary schools, secondary schools, and local educational agencies. Federal agencies must protect surplus equipment deemed educationally useful for potential transfer under this Act. Federal agencies must identify and transfer educationally useful surplus equipment to GSA for distribution to educational or military family recipients after erasing all data storage devices. The Administrator of General Services arranges for the transfer of surplus Federal equipment to educational or military family recipients. Federal agencies must report potential equipment availability in advance to facilitate direct transfers. The Administrator gives preference to educational and military family recipients in equipment transfers. The Administrator of General Services prioritizes educational and military family recipients in transferring surplus Federal equipment. Non-classroom usable equipment is refurbished by a nonprofit before being transferred. Transfers are made at the lowest cost permitted by law. The Administrator of General Services prioritizes transferring surplus Federal equipment to educational and military family recipients at the lowest cost permitted by law. Notice of equipment availability is provided through various means, including the Internet and community announcements. Regional Federal Executive Boards assist in facilitating the transfer process to eligible recipients. The Administrator of General Services will establish rules and procedures for implementing the Act, which supersedes Executive Order No. 12999. This Act does not create any enforceable rights or benefits against the United States or its agencies, officers, or employees.
